FLLquestions.What is it?:
We want to tell you about FLL (FIRST LEGO League) â€” an international robotics program for children and teens, inspiring them to learn, create, and change the world through technology.

ğŸ¯ Goal of FLL:

FLL teaches kids to solve real-world problems through robotics and innovation. Participants work in teams, build LEGO robots, develop projects, and learn to tackle future challenges like protecting the environment or improving people's lives.

ğŸŒ Competition Scale:

Competitions are held worldwide ğŸŒ. More than 110 countries participate in the program! This means that children and teens can exchange experiences with different cultures and learn to work together.

ğŸ”µ Competition Levels:
â€¢ Regional stages
â€¢ National championships
â€¢ International tournaments (World Festival)

ğŸš€ Why participate in FLL?

We believe that participating in FLL provides huge opportunities for the future:
âœ… Developing technical skills â€“ programming, engineering, and design.
âœ… Teamwork skills â€“ learning to work in a team and resolve conflicts.
âœ… Creative thinking â€“ finding non-standard solutions.
âœ… Preparation for a STEM career â€“ helps choose a future profession.
âœ… Networking â€“ meeting people worldwide and finding like-minded individuals.

ğŸ”— Useful Links:
1. Official FIRST Website â€” https://www.firstinspires.org
2. Information about FLL â€” https://www.firstinspires.org/robotics/fll
3. Resources and Materials for Participants â€” https://www.firstlegoleague.org

ğŸ’¡ Tip from us: Actively participate in project work and competitions! This is your chance to improve your skills, make friends worldwide, and even earn scholarships for education.
FLLquestions.Awards:
In the FIRST LEGO League (FLL) 2024-2025 season, titled â€œSubmerged,â€ teams can aim for various awards that recognize their achievements in different competition areas.

ğŸ† Main Awards in FLL:

1. Championâ€™s Award ğŸ¥‡

2. Robot Performance Award ğŸ¤–

3. Robot Design Award ğŸ› ï¸

4. Innovation Project Award ğŸ’¡

5. Core Values Award ğŸŒŸ

6. Breakthrough Award ğŸš€

FLLquestions.About the 2024-2025 Season:
ğŸŒŠ The FIRST LEGO League 2024-2025 Season â€”

This season is called â€œSUBMERGED,â€ exploring the underwater world, solving challenges related to marine ecosystems, and developing innovative solutions for ocean exploration. ğŸŒğŸ¤–

ğŸ¯ Goal of this Season:

We dive into the theme of marine depths to understand how technology can solve real problems related to oceans.

Participants will work on creating a robot that:
Operates on the field ğŸŒŠ, completing underwater-related missions.
Addresses practical problems of oceans and seas.
Helps preserve and explore the ocean depths.

ğŸ¤– Robot Theme of the Season:

This season, robots will operate on a field representing the underwater world, tackling missions such as:

Searching and collecting resources ğŸ .

Rescuing marine creatures ğŸ™.

Building underwater stations ğŸŒ.

Exploring the ocean depths ğŸ³.

Teams must not only build a robot capable of handling these missions but also devise a strategy to earn maximum points.

â“ Why the name â€œSUBMERGEDâ€?

The name was chosen for a reason!

ğŸ”µ â€œSUBMERGEDâ€ symbolizes diving into the unknown â€“ both in the ocean depths and exploring new technologies.

ğŸŒŠ We know more about space than about the oceanâ€™s depths! This seasonâ€™s task is to inspire participants to innovate and research in oceanology.

This season teaches that science and technology can help protect nature and find new solutions for humanityâ€™s future. ğŸ’¡

ğŸ’¡ Tip: While working on the project, think of a real problem related to the ocean. It could be a solution for cleaning water, helping marine inhabitants, or creating new underwater equipment.

FLLquestions.How to Build a Robot?:
ğŸš€ Building a robot for FLL can be both challenging and exciting. Hereâ€™s a step-by-step guide:

1. **Understand the Game Field:**
   Familiarize yourself with the seasonâ€™s missions. Understand the game field, rules, and objectives. Plan your strategy based on the tasks.

2. **Choose the Right Robot Kit:**
   LEGO Mindstorms (EV3 or Spike Prime) is the standard robot kit for FLL. Ensure your team has access to the necessary parts and software.

3. **Start with a Simple Design:**
   Build a basic robot chassis that is stable and balanced. Add wheels, motors, and sensors based on your mission strategy.

4. **Program the Robot:**
   Use LEGOâ€™s software or third-party tools like ROBOTC. Start with basic movements (forward, backward, turn) and gradually add more complex tasks.

5. **Test and Iterate:**
   Test your robot on the actual game field. Identify any issues, make improvements, and optimize your design and programming.

6. **Add Attachments:**
   Create specialized attachments to complete specific missions, such as grabbing, lifting, or pushing objects.

7. **Keep It Organized:**
   Document your design process and maintain a clear strategy. Judges often appreciate teams that explain their design choices.

ğŸ“˜ Tips and Tricks:
â€¢ Use lightweight materials to improve speed and efficiency.
â€¢ Test sensors thoroughly to ensure accuracy.
â€¢ Use gear ratios to enhance power or speed based on mission requirements.

ğŸ”— Useful Links:
â€¢ LEGO Mindstorms Building Guides: https://www.lego.com
â€¢ EV3 Programming Basics: https://ev3lessons.com
â€¢ FLL Tutorials: https://flltutorials.com

ğŸ’¡ Remember: Simplicity is often the key to success. Build a reliable robot first and then work on enhancing it.
FLLquestions.Innovative Project:
ğŸ’¡ The innovative project is a key part of FLL, where teams address a real-world problem related to the seasonâ€™s theme. Hereâ€™s how to approach it:

1. **Research the Problem:**
   Identify a real-world issue related to this seasonâ€™s theme (e.g., underwater ecosystems for the â€œSubmergedâ€ season). Gather information from reliable sources like scientific articles, documentaries, or interviews with experts.

2. **Brainstorm Solutions:**
   Collaborate with your team to come up with innovative ideas. Think creatively and consider how technology or engineering could solve the problem.

3. **Develop Your Solution:**
   Create a prototype, model, or detailed plan of your solution. Use tools like TinkerCAD, Fusion 360, or even LEGO to build your prototype.

4. **Prepare Your Presentation:**
   Showcase your project in a creative way. Use posters, slides, or videos to explain the problem, your solution, and its potential impact. Make it engaging and easy to understand.

5. **Practice Public Speaking:**
   Judges will ask questions, so practice presenting your project confidently. Be prepared to explain your research, design process, and how your solution works.

ğŸ“˜ Tips:
â€¢ Focus on originality and feasibility.
â€¢ Show how your solution aligns with FLLâ€™s core values.
â€¢ Highlight teamwork and collaboration during your presentation.

ğŸ”— Useful Resources:
â€¢ Season-Specific Guidelines: https://www.firstlegoleague.org
â€¢ Innovative Project Examples: https://flltutorials.com
â€¢ Presentation Tips: https://www.ted.com/talks

Remember: The innovative project is your chance to showcase your creativity and problem-solving skills. Good luck!
FLLquestions.Tips from Us:
Here are some tips from the Uly Dala team to help you succeed in FLL:

1. **Plan Early:**
   Start working on your robot and innovative project as soon as possible. Create a timeline and set goals for each week.

2. **Work as a Team:**
   Divide tasks among team members based on their strengths. Regularly communicate and support each other.

3. **Test Everything:**
   Test your robot and project presentation multiple times. Identify potential issues and fix them before the competition.

4. **Learn from Others:**
   Watch videos of past competitions, attend workshops, and talk to experienced teams. Youâ€™ll gain valuable insights and inspiration.

5. **Stay Organized:**
   Keep all your materials, notes, and designs in one place. This will make it easier to track your progress and prepare for judging sessions.

6. **Have Fun:**
   Remember, FLL is about learning, creativity, and teamwork. Enjoy the process and celebrate your achievements, no matter the outcome.

ğŸ’¡ Remember: Every great team starts with small steps. Believe in yourself, stay determined, and always aim higher!

ğŸ”— Useful Links:
â€¢ FIRST LEGO League Community: https://community.firstinspires.org
â€¢ FLL Inspiration Videos: https://www.youtube.com/user/FIRSTLEGOLeague
â€¢ Team Management Tips: https://flltutorials.com

ğŸ† Uly Dala wishes you success and unforgettable moments in FLL!

FTCquestions.What is it?:
ğŸ¤– FTC (FIRST Tech Challenge) is an international robotics competition for students aged 12-18 and a part of the global FIRST (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology) movement.

ğŸ¯ FTC's goal is to develop participants' engineering and programming skills, teach teamwork, problem-solving, and how to use technology to improve the world.

ğŸŒ Competition scale: Over 7,000+ teams from 100+ countries design and program robots to compete in regional and international championships.

ğŸš€ Future benefits: Participating in FTC provides valuable engineering and IT skills, helps with scholarships, and prepares for a career in technology. Participants connect with experts worldwide and learn to bring their ideas to life.
ğŸ”— Learn more at www.firstinspires.org
ğŸ”— Need help? The FIRST community is always ready to assist you! https://t.me/firstkazakhstan
FTCquestions.Awards:
Awards and Alliances in FTC â€” INTO THE DEEP season ğŸ®

FTC recognizes teams for various achievements as well as success in competition matches. Here's an overview of all award categories and key alliances:

ğŸ† Inspire Award â€” the most prestigious award!
Given to a team that sets an example for others. They demonstrate outstanding engineering, programming, and teamwork skills.

ğŸ“š Think Award
Awarded to the team that best documents their design process in the Engineering Portfolio.

ğŸŒ Connect Award
Awarded to a team that actively engages with professionals and connects their project to real-world engineering challenges.

ğŸ’¡ Innovate Award
Recognition for innovative robot designs or unique mechanisms.

ğŸ”¥ Motivate Award
Awarded to a team that inspires others to participate in FIRST and shares their knowledge.

âš™ï¸ Control Award
Given for effective use of sensors, autonomous functions, and software.

ğŸ–Œï¸ Design Award
Recognizes the team with the best industrial robot design.

ğŸ— Judgesâ€™ Award
A special award from the judges for unique achievements that don't fit other categories.

ğŸ… Winner Alliance
The alliance that wins the final matches. It includes an Alliance Captain and two selected partner teams.

ğŸ¥ˆ Finalist Alliance
The alliance that reaches the finals but loses in decisive matches. It also consists of a Captain and two partner teams.

ğŸŒŠ FTC 2024-2025 Season â€” INTO THE DEEP ğŸš€

ğŸ¯ Season Objectives
FIRST designs seasons to inspire students in engineering, programming, and sciences. This season focuses on underwater challenges:

ğŸ”¹ How can robots help save marine ecosystems?

ğŸ’¡ FIRST aims to show how technology can change the world for the better. Each season highlights new relevant themes and teaches teams to find engineering solutions for real problems.

ğŸ¦¾ What do teams do?

ğŸŒ Why is it important?
The INTO THE DEEP season is not just about competitions but also learning:

FTCquestions.How to Build a Robot Base:
How to build a robot base for FTC. Based on our own experience, the info is super helpful for beginners. Links, tips, and tutorials below. Letâ€™s go! ğŸš€

ğŸ”§ 1) Chassis â€” The foundation of any robot

We recommend starting with a basic chassis from GoBilda or REV.
The most popular option is the Strafer Chassis Kit from GoBilda since itâ€™s prepped for wheels and motors.

ğŸ’¡ Our Tip: Choose a chassis with Mecanum Wheels for omnidirectional movement. It gives a huge advantage on the field.

ğŸ“º Chassis assembly tutorial:
ğŸ”— https://youtu.be/dKG-_FvWQ7Q?si=rJOthjnvVZUz-KMk

âš™ï¸ 2) Motors and Wheels

We recommend using HD Hex Motors and Mecanum Wheels for good power and speed.

ğŸ“º Wheel and motor installation tutorial:
ğŸ”— Video: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLnGKI6YfHs_-fQjXAj2DboGclWjR_RPZp&si=l_1edj2e32critpi

ğŸ”‹ 3) Connecting Electronics

We suggest using the Control Hub from REV Robotics. Itâ€™s a universal controller that integrates all robot components.

ğŸ“º Electronics connection tutorial:
ğŸ”— Video: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLnGKI6YfHs_-fQjXAj2DboGclWjR_RPZp&si=l_1edj2e32critpi

ğŸ–±ï¸ 4) Programming the Robot

Once the chassis is assembled and electronics are connected, the next step is programming the robot. Beginners can start with FTC Blocks, while experienced coders can use Java.

ğŸ’¡ Tips from us:
â€¢ Replace standard mounts with 3D-printed parts to make the robot lighter and easier to work with.
â€¢ Use plastic or carbon elements instead of metal to reduce weight and improve speed.
â€¢ Donâ€™t skimp on batteries and chargers! Theyâ€™re crucial for stable performance.

ğŸ”— REV Robotics https://www.revrobotics.com/

FTCquestions.Outreach/Inspire:
ğŸŒ Outreach

Outreach is about spreading the word about your team, robots, and the philosophy of Gracious Professionalism. Itâ€™s a crucial aspect of FTC as it showcases how your team engages with the community and helps others.

ğŸ“‘ What to include in Outreach:

1) Social Media â€” Share your project progress on Instagram, Facebook, or TikTok.
2) Educational Projects â€” Host workshops or lectures for students or kids in summer camps.
3) Collaboration with Other Teams â€” Assist new teams with learning or technical challenges.
4) Volunteer Work â€” Participate in science, technology, or robotics-related events.

ğŸ“‹ Pro Tip:
Plan your events in advance and use hashtags on Instagram and TikTok to reach a larger audience. Examples: #FTCOutreach, #STEMforAll. This will attract attention to both your team and STEM education!

ğŸ† Inspire Award

Inspire is the key award recognizing teams for exceptional contributions to robotics, engagement, and problem-solving with technical and social approaches. To qualify for the Inspire Award, show that your team does more than just build a robotâ€”it inspires, educates, and helps others.

ğŸ“‘ What to include in Inspire:

1) Deep Project Work â€” Demonstrate how your robot solves a real-world problem.
2) Teamwork â€” Focus not only on the robot but also on how you work as a team, communicate, and solve issues.
3) Mission and Philosophy â€” Showcase how your team uses robotics to improve society.

ğŸ“‹ Pro Tip:
Include stories in your portfolio about how your project impacted others and how you addressed social or educational challenges. This creates a stronger case for the Inspire Award.

ğŸ–¼ How to Create a Portfolio with Canva:
1) Register on Canva â€” Sign up on Canva.com if you donâ€™t have an account. Itâ€™s free!
2) Choose a Template â€” Search â€œportfolioâ€ and select a template.
3) Customize Pages â€” Add sections:
â€¢ Technical Details: Describe your robot and solutions.
â€¢ Development Stages: Show your design process.
â€¢ Outreach: Community engagement activities.
4) Add Graphics and Text â€” Insert photos and diagrams of your robot.
5) Download and Share â€” Export as a PDF or PNG.
FTCquestions.Tips from Us:
1. Start with a 3D model of the robot ğŸ–¥ï¸: Before starting the assembly, it is important to create a 3D CAD (Computer-Aided Design) model of the robot. This will help visualize how all the parts will work together and avoid mistakes during assembly. Using tools like Tinkercad or Fusion 360 allows for more precise design and ensures all components fit together perfectly.

2. Plan rest and recovery in advance ğŸ§˜: Planning for rest is key to productivity. Make sure to schedule time for recovery and relaxation in advance. Proper rest helps maintain clear thinking and energy for tackling complex tasks. This way, you'll stay calm and ready for new achievements.

3. Use engineering holes to reduce weight âš™ï¸: When designing parts for the robot, adding holes in areas where they don't affect strength can help reduce the overall weight of the structure. This is especially important for robots where weight plays a role in maneuverability and efficiency. Be sure to consider where you can add holes to reduce weight without weakening the structure.
FTCquestions.FTC Glossary:
1. FTC (FIRST Tech Challenge) ğŸš€ â€” Robotics competition where teams create robots to solve specific tasks.

2. Sample â€” Game elements (balls) for collection and sorting.

3. Basket â€” The goal where samples need to be delivered for points.

4. Chamber â€” A place for temporary storage and sorting of samples.

5. CAD (Computer-Aided Design) ğŸ’» â€” Using computer software to create 3D models of the robot and its components.

6. Gracious Professionalism ğŸ¤ â€” A principle emphasizing respect, helping others, and professional behavior.

7. Drive Team ğŸï¸ â€” The team managing the robot on the field during matches, including the driver, operator, and strategists.

8. Pit ğŸ”§ â€” A place where the team prepares the robot before matches, conducts diagnostics, and makes improvements.

9. Match ğŸ† â€” A competition stage where two teams face off using their robots.

10. Alliance ğŸ¤ğŸ¤– â€” A group of two teams working together in a match to achieve a common goal.

11. Autonomous Period â±ï¸ â€” The part of the match when the robot operates independently based on pre-programmed instructions.

12. Driver-Controlled Period ğŸ® â€” The part of the match when the team manually controls the robot.

13. Award ğŸ… â€” A prize a team can earn for achievements, such as the Inspire Award.

14. Outreach ğŸŒ â€” Team activities promoting STEM, engaging new people, and helping others.
